summary: Very high yielding variety, with rust resistance and good quality at elevations above 1300 meters. Variety not uniform.
additional_argonomic_information: Anacafe 14 is drought tolerant. Anacafe 14 is not uniform; plants are not stable from one generation to the next.

summary: A tall variety that combines high yields, tolerance to coffee leaf rust, resistance to coffee berry disease, and good cup quality.
additional_argonomic_information: Well-adapted for smallholders because of its rare combination of being a tall variety with disease resistance and resillience (e.g., can cope with low management and adverse environmental conditions).
lineage: SL28, SL34, Rume Sudan, N39, K7, SL4 and the Timor Hybrid
breeder: Coffee Research Foundation (now Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization, KALRO)

summary: One of the most culturally and genetically important C. arabica varieties in the world, known for excellent quality in the cup at the highest altitudes.
Vigorous and highly productive tall variety with very good cup quality. Found commonly in Rwanda and Burundi.
Moderate yield, good cup potential, and susceptible to major diseases. Adapted for medium altitudes. Found commonly in Rwanda and Burundi.
Very good cup quality with large beans. An important regional variety in Monagas state in northeastern Venezuela.
additional_argonomic_information: Highly adapted for commercial production in Monagas State in northeastern Venezuela.
lineage: A selection of the Typica variety.

summary: High yielding variety, with exceptional quality at elevations above 1300 meters.
additional_argonomic_information: An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.
lineage: Caturra x Ethiopian wild accession "ET41" (CATIE collection)

summary: High yielding/Dwarf/Compact variety resistant to coffee leaf rust and coffee berry disease. Found commonly in Malawi, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.
additional_argonomic_information: Requires careful management to maximize yield without overbearing.
lineage: Selection of a Catimor breeding line from Colombia (Caturra x Timor Hybrid 1343)

summary: Adapted to warmest zones and acidic soils. High yielding.
additional_argonomic_information: Susceptible to Ojo de Gallo. Adapted to warmest zones and acidic soils.

summary: A compact plant with high yielding potential of standard quality in Central America. Very high susceptibility to coffee leaf rust.
A compact plant with good yielding potential of standard quality in Central America. Very high susceptibility to coffee leaf rust.
lineage: Natural mutation of the Bourbon variety

summary: Very high yielding with very good quality potential if planted in healthy soil and at elevations >1300 meters, with resistance to rust. Well-adapted for agroforestry.
additional_argonomic_information: May have difficulty establishing roots in the first two years. Requires careful nutrition for roots to become established, avoiding too much nitrogen (N). An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.

summary: High yielding variety adapted to warmest zones and acidic soils.
additional_argonomic_information: Recently, Costa Rica 95 has been confirmed through scientific evaluation to be susceptible to coffee leaf rust in Costa Rica and may also be susceptible in other areas of Central America. Susceptible to Ojo de Gallo. Recommended for acidic soils and soils rich in aluminum. Recommended for warmest zones.
breeder: Instituto del Cafe_ de Costa Rica (ICAFE)

summary: Well-adapted to medium altitudes. Resistant to coffee leaf rust and some nematodes.
additional_argonomic_information: Nematode resistance: Not resistant to Pratylenchus spp. It is resistant to Meloidogyne exigua.
breeder: Fundacio_n Salvadoreña para Investigaciones del Café (PROCAFÉ)  an

summary: Variety with very high productivity, tolerance to rust, and very good quality. Excellent adaptation to humid environments.
additional_argonomic_information: Excellent adaptation to humid environments. An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.
lineage: T5296 x Ethiopian Local Variety accession "ET25" (from the CATIE collection)

summary: Very high yielding variety at elevations at high altitudes.
additional_argonomic_information: May have difficulty establishing roots in the first two years due to an imbalance between root growth and aerial parts. Requires careful nutrition for the roots to become properly established; avoid excess of nitrogen. An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.
lineage: Naryelis (Catimor) x Ethiopian landrace accession "ET06" (CATIE collection)

summary: Early production and high yielding plant resistant to coffee leaf rust. Well- adapted to low and medium altitudes. Found primarily in Puerto Rico.
additional_argonomic_information: Variety not homogenous; presents a non-specified amount of segregation in the field. Susceptible to coffee leaf miner.

summary: Panamanian Geisha has exceptionally high quality at high altitudes. The term "Geisha" is often applied to other coffees that do not share the distinct genetics of Panamanian Geisha. Geisha is also cultivated widely in Malawi. coffees that do not share the distinct genetics of Panamanian Geisha. Geisha is also cultivated widely in Malawi.
High yielding variety, with very good quality at elevations above 1300 meters.
additional_argonomic_information: Stature is intermediate between Dwarf/Compact and tall. An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.
lineage: Caturra x Ethiopian landrace accession "E531'' (CATIE collection)

summary: High yielding with very good cup quality potential, but susceptible to the major diseases and prone to die back. This is the Harar variety sometimes found in Rwanda (no longer recommended by Rwandan coffee authorities because of its short productive life)
additional_argonomic_information: Many varieties or populations share the name Harar, but are not necessarily the same. This is the Harar variety sometimes found in Rwanda. It is no longer recommended by the Rwandan coffee authorities because of its short productive life.
lineage: Typica-like genetic background, introduced to Rwanda in 1956.

summary: High yielding plant adapted to medium altitudes. Resistant to coffee leaf rust and some nematodes.
additional_argonomic_information: Nematodes: Not resistant to Pratylenchus spp. It is resistant to Meloidogyne exigua.

summary: High yielding plant adapted to lowest altitudes. Requires high fertilization.
additional_argonomic_information: Recently, IHCAFE 90 has been confirmed through scientific evaluation to be susceptible to coffee leaf rust in Honduras and maybe possibly also be susceptible in other areas of Central America. Highly susceptible to Ojo de Gallo.

summary: Very vigorous and highly productive. Found commonly in Rwanda and Burundi.
lineage: A selection of Jackson. Bourbon-like genetic background.

summary: High quality in Central America. Tolerant to major diseases, with low fertilizer requirement. Good choice for smallholder farmers.
Tolerant to coffee leaf rust and coffee berry disease. Found primarily in Kenya and Tanzania.
additional_argonomic_information: K7 is distinguished by its spreading habit on young laterals although older primaries tend to droop. It has characteristic medium to narrow leaves with young shoot-tips that are light bronze in color. It is suited for lower altitudes where coffee leaf rust is prevalent.
lineage: Selected from French Mission. Bourbon-like genetic background.
breeder: Individual farmer selection: R.H. Walker in Kenya in 1936

summary: Tolerant of drought and coffee leaf rust but highly susceptible to coffee berry disease. Found mostly in Uganda.
additional_argonomic_information: Drought tolerant. Some tolerance to White Stem Borer has been documented.
lineage: A selection of Kent. Likely Bourbon-like genetic background.

summary: High yielding variety adapted to warmest zones and acidic soils.
additional_argonomic_information: Recently, Lempira has been confirmed through scientific evaluation to be susceptible to coffee leaf rust in Honduras and maybe possibly also be susceptible in other areas of Central America. Susceptible to Ojo de Gallo. Recommended for acidic soils and soils rich aluminium. Recommended for warmest zones.

summary: An elusive Puerto Rican variety.
additional_argonomic_information: "True" Limani is very difficult to find because of issues with genetic traceability dating to its original release in Puerto Rico. Consequently, plants identified as Limani rarely match the original reference. This doesn’t necessarily mean that plants identified as Limani won’t perform well, only that it is difficult to predict performance, for example, or resistance to coffee leaf rust. True Limani is supposed to be well adapted to medium altitudes (above 1000 m) and rust resistant.

summary: Good to very good cup quality in Central America, but highly susceptible to rust. Very low yielding, large leaves and large internodes.
additional_argonomic_information: Due to the low productivity of Maragogipe, Pacamara is considered a better option. Maragogipe beans are especially large, and the plant also has unusually large spacing between internodes and leaf size.

summary: High yielding plant adapted to medium altitudes. Notably high acidity in the cup.
lineage: Timor Hybrid 832/2 x Villa Sarchi CIFC 971/10

summary: Exceptional cup quality and drought tolerant, but highly susceptible to major diseases. Important variety for smallholder coffee growers in Rwanda and Burundi.
additional_argonomic_information: Drought tolerant and resilient (e.g., can cope with low management and adverse environmental conditions).

summary: Very high-yielding variety, with rust resistance and good quality at elevations above 1300 meters. Variety not uniform.
additional_argonomic_information: An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.

summary: Compact variety with very good cup quality and large beans, tolerance to coffee leaf rust and nematodes, and high yield potential. An important regional variety in Venezuela.
additional_argonomic_information: Monte Claro is a cultivar that can tolerate significant levels of aluminum in the soil and weather variation. It grows very well in medium shade. It is highly adapted to different conditions and geographic regions of Venezuela.
lineage: Timor Hybrid 832/2 x Villa Sarchi CIFC 971/11

summary: Very high yielding variety if planted in healthy soil, with very good quality at elevations above 1300 meters. Well-adapted to agroforestery conditions.
additional_argonomic_information: Nematodes: Variety not resistant to Pratylenchus spp. Is resistant to some Meloidogyne spp. An important note about F1 hybrids: Seeds taken from hybrid plants will not have the same characteristics as the parent plants. This is called “segregation.” It means that the child plant will not look or behave the same as the parent, with potential losses of yield, disease resistance, quality, or other agronomic performance traits. The variety should only be reproduced through clonal propagation and purchased from trusted nurseries.
lineage: T5296 x wild Ethiopian accession "ET01" (CATIE collection)

summary: A vigorous and productive plant with good quality cup but susceptible to major diseases. Grown widely in South America, but rarely in Central America and the Caribbean.
additional_argonomic_information: In Peru, recommended elevation is >1500m.

summary: High yielding variety at high altitudes with very good cup quality.
lineage: Naryelis (Catimor) x wild Ethiopian accession "ET26" (CATIE collection)

summary: A Robusta variety used for rootstock grafting because of its high resistance to nematodes. Arabica plants (any variety) can be grafted onto Nemaya roostock to make the plant resistant to nematodes.
lineage: C. canephora T3561 x C. canephora T3751

summary: Good cup quality, but susceptible to major diseases. Preferred by smallholder farmers in Uganda.
additional_argonomic_information: Resilient variety (e.g., can cope with low management and adverse environmental conditions).

summary: A high yielding, rust-resistant Brazilian variety recently introduced to Costa Rica.
lineage: Timor Hybrid 832/2 x Villa Sarchi CIFC 971/10

summary: Adapted to warmest zones and acidic soils. High yielding.
breeder: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Forestales, Agr√≠colas y Pecuarias (INIFAP), Mexico

summary: Capable of producing exceptional cup quality. Very high susceptibility to coffee leaf rust. Variety not uniform; plants are not stable from one generation to the next.
additional_argonomic_information: Pacamara is not homogeneous; plants are not stable from one generation to the next.
breeder: Instituto Salvadoreño de Investigaciones del Café (ISIC)

summary: Standard quality in Central America. Very high susceptibility to coffee leaf rust.
breeder: Instituto Salvadoreño de Investigaciones del Café (ISIC)

summary: A compact plant with medium yield and good quality, but highly susceptible to major diseases.

summary: High yielding with tolerance to drought, coffee leaf rust, and coffee berry disease. Adapted to a wide range of ecosystems. Found mostly in Rwanda.
additional_argonomic_information: Drought tolerant. Significantly prone to die back.
lineage: A selection of BMJ (Blue Mountain Jamaica) in Rwanda, related to but distinct from Typica.

summary: High yielding tall variety resistant to rust and coffee berry disease recently released in Rwanda.
additional_argonomic_information: Vigorous.
lineage: A selection of the Indian variety Sln.6 (Kent x C. robusta). A population composite variety.

summary: High-yielding, Dwarf/Compact hybrid tolerant to coffee leaf rust and resistant to coffee berry disease (CBD). Released in Kenya.
breeder: Coffee Research Foundation (now Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization, KALRO)

summary: A high-yielding tall variety with drought and cold tolerance. Found mostly in Kenya and Uganda.
additional_argonomic_information: Drought and cold tolerant.

summary: Drought tolerant and very good cup quality potential, but susceptible to major diseases. Found commonly in Kenya, Malawi, Uganda, Zimbabwe.
lineage: Selection of "Tanganika Drought Resistant." Bourbon-like genetic background.

summary: Exceptional cup quality but highly susceptible to coffee berry disease. Found mostly in Kenya.

summary: One of the most culturally and genetically important C. arabica coffees in the world, with high quality in Central America. Very high susceptibility to coffee leaf rust, well-adapted to the coldest conditions.
